name: Reading Into a New China I: Population, Youth, Marriage, & Housing

prereqs.text: (82-235 [] at least D) or (82-232 [] at least D)

long_desc: This 9unit course is designed for students who have reached the intermediate level of proficiency in the use of Chinese language to develop their language process competency in all four skills to a more advanced level. Students will expand explicit knowledge of sociocultural influences on Chinese language use, and be able to apply the knowledge to conduct culturally appropriate spoken and written communication across various social domains and genres. Topics to be covered in this class will be closely related to current social issues in China, such as population, youth culture, love  marriage and housing. Students will also develop a repertoire of strategies and resources to assist their learning so that they will gradually become autonomous learners who are able to conduct independent learning of the Chinese language, culture, history, and society. Classroom discussion and essay writing will be the major forms of work throughout the semester. Research projects on Chinese culture and society are also a requirement so that students will be able to gain a deeper understanding of the cultural background of the language.

custom_fields.goals: For this course, students are expected toExplain the social and cultural issues related to population, youth culture, love marriage and housing in modern China, as well as analyze how these issues affect Chinese peoples perception of their living condition, cultural identity and heritage, and their connections with and views of the world. Analyze the historical, social and cultural background of the aforementioned issues. Through intercultural comparison, evaluate how different positions and worldviews affect peoples perception and interpretations of similar issues in different regions.Describe the historical and social origins and contexts of certain cultural norms, andevaluate how these cultural norms have become entrenched in peoples thinking to create and perpetuate structural inequalities and discriminatory attitudes in different societies, including their own.Enhance their language skills by using more abstract and sophisticated words, more complicated grammar and sentence structures, and more coherent paragraphlevel argumentations to express their opinions, in speaking and writing, on those social and cultural issues.
custom_fields.key_topics: Chinese language, communication, modern Chinese society and culture, including population, youth culture, love & marriage and housing.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Intermediate Chinese 2, placement, or permission of the instructor.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: 8 homework, 4 online unit tests, 4 short essays, 1 research paper, presentations and oral activities, weekly preview/review assignments, classroom discussion.
custom_fields.relevance:
DC GenEd: Intercultural and Global Inquiry

This course further enhances students' communicative abilities in Chinese at the advanced level and enriches their intercultural understanding of modern Chinese society and culture from a global perspective. It helps students develop critical thinking skills on socio-cultural issues related to China and the world.
custom_fields.learning_resources: A Changing China: Part 1 (Textbook). Movies, TV programs and online materials provided by the instructor
